title: 111_hr3737
content: The "Small Business Microlending Expansion Act of 2009" allows intermediaries to report borrower information to credit agencies for credit building. It also provides flexibility in credit terms for small businesses. SEC. 3. FLEXIBLE CREDIT TERMS. Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act is amended to remove "short-term" in various paragraphs. SEC. 4. INCREASED PROGRAM PARTICIPATION. Section 7(m)(2) of the Small Business Act is amended to require individuals involved in making microloans to have specific experience or employ someone with experience in the field. The Small Business Act now requires individuals making microloans to have at least 1 year of experience providing intensive marketing, management, and technical assistance to borrowers, or employ a full-time staff member with similar experience. SEC. 5 increases the limit on intermediary borrowing to $1,000,000 and $7,000,000, with the option to treat it as $10,000,000 if deemed appropriate. SEC. 6 expands borrower education assistance to 35 percent. SEC. 7 introduces the Young Entrepreneurs Program. Section 7(m)(4) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Young Entrepreneurs Program, allowing intermediaries to provide technical assistance to young entrepreneurs in establishing small businesses and securing financing. The Young Entrepreneurs Program allows intermediaries to provide technical assistance to individuals aged 25 or younger who have resided in the served geographic area for at least 2 years. The Young Entrepreneurs Program requires young entrepreneurs who receive technical assistance from an intermediary to make a good faith effort to establish or operate their small business in the geographic area served by the intermediary. If a small business concern operated by a young entrepreneur receives a loan, repayment may be deferred. If a small business operated by a young entrepreneur receives a loan, repayment can be deferred for up to 6 months from the final disbursement. SEC. 8. INTEREST RATES AND LOAN SIZE amended to increase loan size from $7,500 to $10,000. SEC. 9. REPORTING REQUIREMENT. Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a reporting requirement for the Administrator to submit a report to the Committees on Small Business detailing the names, locations, and funding amounts of intermediaries in the microloan program. The amended Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act requires the Administrator to report on the names, locations, and funding amounts of intermediaries in the microloan program, along with details on loans, grants, contributions from non-Federal sources, and microloans made to specific groups like women, low-income, veteran, and disabled entrepreneurs. The report under the amended Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act includes details on the marketing, management, and technical assistance provided by intermediaries to various groups such as women, low-income, veteran, disabled, and minority entrepreneurs and business owners. The report includes details on the number of jobs created, repayment history, and success of businesses after receiving microloans and assistance from intermediaries. SEC. 10. Surplus interest rate subsidy for businesses. The Administrator can make grants to intermediaries to reduce interest rates for borrowers under this subsection. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2010 and 2011 totaling $200 million for technical assistance grants, direct loans, and interest assistance grants under section 7(m) of the Small Business Act. SEC. 12. REGULATIONS. The Administrator must issue regulations within 180 days of the enactment of this Act to carry out its provisions.
